title: The Rare Gift of Seeing Extra Colors
sub_head: Research on colorblindness has led to a new understanding of tetrachromacy, an inherited ability to perceive subtle shades
body:
In 2015, the internet was consumed by debate over whether the dress in a certain photograph was blue and black or white and gold. It was a compelling reminder that color isn’t “out there” in the world but within each of us. In fact, for certain rare individuals, recent research on human vision has found that the world they see is more colorful than most of us can imagine.
Human beings are “trichromats”—that is, the cones in our eyes are sensitive to three frequencies of light: long-wavelength reds, medium-wavelength greens and short-wavelength blues. As this trio reacts, in differing intensities and combinations, our brain compares their outputs to create the perception of color. If red and green cones are activated, we perceive yellows and oranges, whereas differing combinations of green with blue cones can make teals and turquoises, and blue with red cones might make violets and indigos.
